subject: crater
title: Customer's Primary Currency should convert to my Preferred Currency.
description:
I'm a new user of Crater, having made the move from Wave Invoicing. I previously used Wave but they're limiting their services to only the US and Canada and potentially abroad businesses (like myself) in the future.

One thing that Wave Invoicing allowed me to do was invoice my customers using their currencies. So my American clients got their invoices in USD. My Dubai-based clients got their invoices in AED.

I saw that Crater did this, too, hence why I made the shift, finding it the closest and aesthetically most pleasing invoicing software to Wave that I've found.

However In Reports on Wave Invoicing, all invoiced currencies were converted (approximately) to my preferred currency (AED).

I noticed that after manually migrating my invoices from Wave Invoicing to Crater that my USD invoices did not convert to my preferred currency (AED). For example, the a 2,500 USD invoice shows up as 2,500 AED, throwing the reports and monthly chart off.

I do not code nor know how to. I'm not sure if this is a bug or if this is a feature that needs to be worked into the platform or is this something I have to do from my side?

Any insight would be great!

@JadeMerle currency rates are moving rapidly. To tackle this issue, you can create a custom field with the foreign currency you wish to display (USD) and add the value manually at the current currency rates.

title: Also add the possibility to add invoices and estimates as attachments in emails
description:
Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.

Describe the solution you'd like It would be useful to have the option to add the invoice/estimate as an attachment instead of a link to generate them in the emails. If we want to have crater on an internal network only, customers won't have access to the links and they cannot generate their invoices/estimates. This would mean that we need to manual generate them, save them, and attach and send the email manually. Also, I am not 100% sure, but the existing method might not be GDPR compliant since anyone with the link can have access to the invoice.

Hi Mr. Mohit,

Installation fails during initial configuration, no error on the navigator.

The initial configuration after the docker-compose installation is compose of 7 steps, but when I continue from third to fourth step configuration "fails" and navigator jumps directly to the login page. As there is no user configured it's impossible to access to the app.

  • Composer 1.8.4 2019-02-11

OS release: Debian GNU/Linux 10 (buster) On a Raspberry Pi 4

I hope this information is sufficient to reproduce the issue.

Regards,

Hey @aorvay, Thanks for the details.

Your App Domain needs to match the URL that you're accessing the website from otherwise it will not work. Crater uses Laravel Sanctum for authentication and the field APP_DOMAIN is needed in order to authenticate all the requests.

Also, I'd suggest creating a virtual host or access your website from a URL like http://crater.test or just http://localhost:8880 instead of the IP Address.

Also @aorvay, please note that APP_DOMAIN should not contain http:// or https:// in front of the URL.

If you're browsing on a different port like localhost:8880, then the APP_DOMAIN should include the port: localhost:8880

Thanks a lot Mohit, works!!

It's possible to define negative VAT's? in some cases in Spain, VAT could be negative and the app didn't allow!

Regards,

Glad to know that it worked out @aorvay 👍

Regarding Negative tax, currently thats not possible.

There’s already an open issue regarding this: https://github.com/bytefury/crater/issues/315

subject: crater
title: Can't login behind Nginx reverse proxy
description:
I'm running the latest version of Carter App behind a Nginx reverse proxy.

In the .env file I have the correct SACTUM_STATEFULL_DOMAINS and SESSION_DOMAIN settings according to the domain name.

When I try to login, I always get the following error.

There is an active internet connection on server. Also, If I reload the page, user redirects to dashboard.

Any help or idea?

thank you.

This is the Nginx proxy configuration:

`server { server_name craterapp.domain.com;

    location / {

    proxy_set_header X-Real-IP $remote_addr;
    proxy_set_header    X-Forwarded-For $proxy_add_x_forwarded_for;
    proxy_set_header Host $host;
    proxy_set_header X-Forwarded-Proto $scheme;
     proxy_pass http://craterapp_ip;

}

listen 443 ssl; # managed by Certbot
ssl_certificate /etc/letsencrypt/live/craterapp.domain.com/fullchain.p$
ssl_certificate_key /etc/letsencrypt/live/craterapp.domain.com/privkey$
include /etc/letsencrypt/options-ssl-nginx.conf; # managed by Certbot
ssl_dhparam /etc/letsencrypt/ssl-dhparams.pem; # managed by Certbot

}

server { if ($host = craterapp.domain.com) { return 301 https://$host$request_uri; } # managed by Certbot

    listen 80;
    server_name craterapp.domain.com;
return 404; # managed by Certbot

}`

I've just updated from 3.1 and I'm getting the same issue. Because it's running without SSL inside the container (and the proxy is providing the SSL), it's trying to redirect to a HTTP url, rather than HTTPS. Is there a way to force it to think its running on HTTPS?

Thanks
I can fix the redirect issue by editing app/Http/Middleware/TrustProxies.php and adding protected $proxies = '*';. However I'm still getting a 401 on the bootstrap request.

@SteveEdson

On app/Providers/RouteServiceProvider.php

Can you update this line to following:

FROM THIS public const HOME = '/admin/dashboard';

TO THIS: public const HOME = 'https://your-domain/admin/dashboard';

Please don't forget to replace the URL (https://your-domain) with your actual domain.

@mohitpanjwani unfortunately, that isn't the issue. I can fix the redirect by editing the trusted proxies mentioned above. The issue is now that although I can successfully log in, subsequent calls are failing telling me that I'm unauthenticated.

Also worth mentioning that the mobile app is working fine, just seems to be an issue with the web app.

In that case its an issue with sanctum.

Can you share the values in .env file for: session_domain and sanctum_stateful_domains variables?

Ah thats fixed it, thanks. I was upgrading from an older version that didn't have these in the .env.example file. Is it worth adding an exception if these variables aren't set?

Thanks for the help

I have mentioned the same on the upgrade guide but you’re right.

We should add an exception/error message that explains it better 👌

subject: crater
title: Crater ignores From Mail Name
description:
Firstly, a huge thanks to the developers of Crater. My small business would be lost without it! I'm wondering about a minor issue with how emails are addressed.

As we all know, emails can be sent using a short address such as billing@company.com or a full name, such as John Smith <billing@company.com>. Using full names greatly improves mail deliverability, in some cases, dramatically. Crater allows the user to specify a From Mail Name. This name is used for the "Test Mail Configuration" feature, but not when invoices are sent. Is there some way to do this that I'm missing? When my server sends out invoices, they are frequently marked as spam, because they do not contain a name.

It also stands to reason that Crater should format To: addresses the same way. Gmail, for example, will almost always mark messages as spam if they are sent to johnsmith@gmail.com instead of John Smith <johnsmith@gmail.com>. Why wouldn't Crater take advantage of the fact that every single Customer in the system has a full name and address mails properly?
+1 for this feature request!

subject: crater
title: Crater ignores From Mail Name
description:
Firstly, a huge thanks to the developers of Crater. My small business would be lost without it! I'm wondering about a minor issue with how emails are addressed.

As we all know, emails can be sent using a short address such as billing@company.com or a full name, such as John Smith <billing@company.com>. Using full names greatly improves mail deliverability, in some cases, dramatically. Crater allows the user to specify a From Mail Name. This name is used for the "Test Mail Configuration" feature, but not when invoices are sent. Is there some way to do this that I'm missing? When my server sends out invoices, they are frequently marked as spam, because they do not contain a name.

It also stands to reason that Crater should format To: addresses the same way. Gmail, for example, will almost always mark messages as spam if they are sent to johnsmith@gmail.com instead of John Smith <johnsmith@gmail.com>. Why wouldn't Crater take advantage of the fact that every single Customer in the system has a full name and address mails properly?
+1 for this feature request!

title: Important: Currencies with 3 digits of precision
description: I have add a new currency (Bahraini Dinar - BHD) manually from the DB and it has 3 digits precision, formatting looks fine as it shows 3 decimal places but when adding a new invoice the system rounds the last digit. for Ex. if the invoice amount is 12.435 once submitted it becomes 12.430 and it's saved in the DB as 1243.

@Hujairi Hey, It's currently not possible to create invoices with 3 digits of precision. Its DB Structure & everything is designed to work with only 2 digit precision.

I think it'll need a lot more work & testing in order to support more than 2 digits :)

I'll try to see if we can improve this. Meanwhile, if you have any suggestions regarding how to handle this, please feel free to comment.

as far as i see that numbers are being multiplied and divided by 100 for 2 digit currencies, it might help if that number is dynamic as (10 to the power of currency precision) and by that you won't have to change any structure in the DB.

as far as i see that numbers are being multiplied and divided by 100 for 2 digit currencies, it might help if that number is dynamic as (10 to the power of currency precision) and by that you won't have to change any structure in the DB.

Yes, you're right about this. I actually looked more into this after my comment.

We're already using integers for all the currency values. Except for percentages.

Also, we already have a precision column on the currencies table, so we can use that to allow 3 digits of precision but need to test further.

title: Incorrect due amount when creating payments
description:
Describe the bug I've created an invoice and recorded a payment against it. Saving the payment was successful, however, when I was taken back to the list of invoices it stated that the invoice was partially paid, the due amount was £0.01.

Expected behavior There shouldn't have been any outstanding amount after the invoice was fully paid.

Screenshots There is a check in the Payment model at line 144. I've dumped the values: the invoice's due amount and the amount sent in the request, see the results in the bottom-right corner of the screenshot:

It seems that the amount sent in the request is invalid and casting the type to integer results in this weird behaviour.

Please complete the following information: - Crater version: 4.0.1 - PHP version: 7.4.13 - Database type and version: MySQL 5.7

Optional info - OS: Elementary OS - Browser: firefox, brave

Here is the problem: $ grep -RHni float app/ app/Models/Estimate.php:53: 'discount' => 'float', app/Models/EstimateItem.php:31: 'discount' => 'float', app/Models/EstimateItem.php:32: 'quantity' => 'float', app/Models/Invoice.php:51: 'discount' => 'float', app/Models/InvoiceItem.php:34: 'discount' => 'float', app/Models/InvoiceItem.php:35: 'quantity' => 'float', app/Models/Tax.php:32: 'percent' => 'float' app/Models/TaxType.php:22: 'percent' => 'float'

Floats are not suitable for currency mathematics. A decimal type with rounding should be used instead.
I'm looking into this 👀

This issue has been fixed on https://github.com/bytefury/crater/releases/tag/4.0.2.

title: Timezone of settings doesn't work
description:
Hello, I have found that the timezone of company's settings doesn't work.

The method handle (in app/Http/Middleware/ConfigMiddleware.php) loaded after Laravel's LoadConfiguration:

in vendor\laravel\framework\src\Illuminate\Foundation\Bootstrap\LoadConfiguration.php

public function bootstrap(Application $app)
{
    // ...
    date_default_timezone_set($config->get('app.timezone', 'UTC'));
}

in app\Http\Middleware\ConfigMiddleware.php

public function handle($request, Closure $next)
{
    if (\Storage::disk('local')->has('installed')) {
        $setting = CompanySetting::getSetting('time_zone', $request->header('company'));
        $timezone = config('app.timezone');
        if ($setting && $setting != null && $setting != $timezone) {
            config(['app.timezone' => $setting]);
        }
    }

subject: crater
title: Credit/Debit notes
description:
Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe. In some countries it's mandatory to be able to create a Credit & Debit note and have this stated on the invoice.

E.g. A customer returns one of his ordered products and wants his money back, so you create a credit note stating the amount that will be paid back to the customer.

Explanation (probably better as mine) from the world wide web 😄 :

A credit note is a document issued to record in your accounts that a particular amount was returned to the customer for a paid (or partially paid) invoice. It is also sent to your customer to indicate the cancellation of the payment in the original invoice. ~ https://debitoor.com/dictionary/credit-note

A debit note is for purchases made by your own business.

Explanation (probably better as mine) from the world wide web 😄 :

In other words, a debit note basically acts as a buyer's formal request for a credit note from the seller. The document therefore serves as evidence to support a purchase return in the accounting books of a buyer. ~ https://debitoor.com/dictionary/debit-note

Describe the solution you'd like A separate tab where you can create and manage credit & debit notes or a sub section on the invoices & expenses overview so you can create a new credit & debit note. This should be reflected in the sales & expenses accordingly. It's important that the invoice states that it's a debit or credit note (according to the use case) rather as the word "invoice" on the PDF. It would also be nice if it was possible to reference the credit/debit note to a previously entered invoice or expense.

Describe alternatives you've considered None
+1 This would be nice :)
Maybe something that could get added to the roadmap? :-)

subject: crater
title: [Docker] Change MariaDB Docker image from official to linuxserver/mariadb
description:
I was trying to have the docker image run on a Raspberry Pi, and it would always fails because the official MariaDB image from Docker Hub is pretty specify of the supported architecture.

Changing the base image from the official to linuxserver/mariadb makes it work on the Raspi (4, at least) as this one supports multiarch without any trouble. I know we want to usually keep away from anything non official, but linuxserver/mariadb is updated often, and has a large following, so I'm betting it's safe to use if it's to enable multiarch ! :)

I'll let you decide, of course.

I don't have any experience with Raspberry Pi but I was actually looking to use MySQL instead of MariaDB here.

Does the official mysql image work on Raspberry Pi?

They don't. They actually only support less architecture than the official MariaDB image !

I honestly can't tell you why. I read some places it was because the upstream packages of MySQL / MariaDB was not officially supported by their maintainer to work on ARM / other architecture. Like... Not that it doesn't work, it's just they don't bother supporting it themselves, so the team behind official Docker images won't take the risk of becoming temselves maintainer of those versions.

And that's where some "unofficial" images maintained by the community comes into play! :)

oh, I see! Thanks for the information @jpmurray.

I've merged your other PRs but we'll stick to official image for the time being. We'll think about updating if more people request this.
Perfect, I'll just keep myself a branch for my particular use case for the moment! :)

subject: crater
title: Anyplan to move the business logic outside controller?
description:
Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe. Upon checking the code, all of the the logic lives inside the controller. It will be hard for us to separate the methods per Single Responsibility.

The benefits of moving out the logic: * We could apply unit testing per methods, feature/functional will be absolutely great but we don't cover every line of codes. * Mockable methods for huge conditions that requires data from the database yet we could easily return fake values using mocking tools to bypass that condition for nested if-statements. * Re-usable codes for outside project. * Extendable codes with your own unique namespace, e.g: ByFury\Crater\Core

Lacking in this Project: * Unit Testing * Coverage * Extendable/Inheritable Classes * Support as a vendor package, where developers could composer require this package instead of downloading as a boilerplate.

Hey @daison12006013! Those are some very good suggestions but at the moment our focus is on releasing the pending features on the Roadmap.

We've already added feature tests but we'll look into adding unit tests soon as time permits.

Other than that, we have no plans of supporting crater as a composer package as we prefer to keep Crater as a standalone application
Alright.

Advantage of cloud storage backup solution would mean they are not stored on the server and so on event of server failure or other data access-limiting problems the data is restorable and safe.

This could supposedly use the dropbox flysystem driver (https://laravel.com/docs/master/filesystem#custom-filesystems) to upload an exported csv or backup that is done to the user-specified schedule.

One example of a similar functionality/implementation is in the UpDraftPlus plugin for WordPress - backup on a schedule and when complete is uploaded to the cloud storage driver/provider. e.g. for dropbox it stores the backups in Dropbox / Apps / UpDraftPlus / *.

subject: crater
title: Tax type percentages should support more than two decimal places
description:
Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe. Crater presently supports custom tax types with two decimal place precision.

In Québec, we have a provincial tax rate of 9.975%, which cannot be entered in the GUI, nor stored in the DB.

Describe the solution you'd like 1) Modification to the taxes table's percent field to allow for 3 decimal place precision $table->decimal('percent', 5, 3);

2) Modification to TaxTypeModal.vue to allow for 3 decimal place precision: defaultInput: { decimal: '.', thousands: ',', prefix: '% ', precision: 3, masked: false }

Describe alternatives you've considered I've created a fork at https://github.com/gbro115/crater, however it would be great to have this in the original repo.

Good point. but have you tested the implementation?

If it works, can you create a PR for the same?

Thanks

subject: crater
title: Multi currency support
description: Please add support for multiple currencies. e.g. EUR and USD at the same time (Ability to select currency when creating an invoice, product, expenses)
you can already select the type of currency you want to use in an invoice or do you mean per item line? Expenses would be good. Wouldn't be hard for you to implement.

Hi,

If I create an invoice in different currencies it all gets merged in statistics. It's required to split statistics into currencies and make some type of selector, so you could see figures in USD, EUR, etc. separately.

Hi guys,

Is this project still supported? Can you please advise when we can expect a new version. Looks like it's moving too slowly.

Hey guys,

Apologies for the delay. We are working on the update but its a pretty big one and it will take atleast a month before its out.

Meanwhile to fix many small issues, we will release a minor version update for that.

For the major update, We decided to rebuild all the components in tailwind, update to latest laravel version, implement unit tests, feature tests and work on a better release process so we can deliver new updates much faster.

subject: crater
title: Crater ignores MAIL_FROM_ADDRESS when sending email
description:
Describe the bug Crater ignores MAIL_FROM_ADDRESS when sending email and sends with email used by an authorized administrator.

An authorized admin can use non-accounting email. It can lead to issues for outgoing emails. Example from my setup: email server blocks outgoing emails what sent from email what its not in allowed list Config example: smtp account: send@domain.tld, from address: invoice@domain.tld, authorized admin email: manager@domain.tld send@domain.tld is allowed to send emails from invoice@domain.tld but not from manager@domain.tld

Mailserver log: postfix/submission/smtpd[378]: NOQUEUE: reject: RCPT from XXXXXXXX: 553 5.7.1 <manager@domain.tld>: Sender address rejected: not owned by user send@domain.tld; from=<manager@domain.tld> to=<xxxxxxx@xxxxxxx.xxx> proto=ESMTP helo=<xxxxxxxx>

Laravel log: ``` [2020-01-26 xx:xx:xx] production.ERROR: Expected response code 354 but got code "554", with message "554 5.5.1 Error: no valid recipients " {"userId":1,"exception":"[object] (Swift_TransportException(code: 554): Expected response code 354 but got code \"554\", with message \"554 5.5.1 Error: no valid recipients \" at /app/vendor/swiftmailer/swiftmailer/lib/classes/Swift/Transport/AbstractSmtpTransport.php:457) [stacktrace]

0 /app/vendor/swiftmailer/swiftmailer/lib/classes/Swift/Transport/AbstractSmtpTransport.php(341): Swift_Transport_AbstractSmtpTransport->assertResponseCode('554 5.5.1 Error...', Array)

\1 /app/vendor/swiftmailer/swiftmailer/lib/classes/Swift/Transport/EsmtpTransport.php(305): Swift_Transport_AbstractSmtpTransport->executeCommand('DATA\ ', Array, Array, false, NULL) ```

Expected behavior MAIL_FROM_ADDRESS should be used for outgoing emails OR, alternatively (better for supporting multiple companies in future), from a new field like accounting email in "Company info" settings tab).

Please complete the following information: - Crater version: 2.1.0 - PHP version: 7.3-FPM

Optional info - docker (latest version)

subject: crater
title: Allow customers to pay using Stripe
description:
Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe. I would love to be able to accept payments from customers using Stripe.

Describe the solution you'd like When sending an email to customers, they would contain a link to the invoice as well as a link to pay online, and Crater would use the Stripe SDK to process payments and record payments.

It would entail adding the Stripe SDK, settings for Stripe API keys, and a new view/controller to handle payments.

Sample code for processing a payment through Stripe, taken from a similar project I built for myself:

```php try { $charge = \Stripe\Charge::create([ 'amount' => $request->input('amount') * 100, 'currency' => 'usd', 'description' => $description, 'source' => $request->input('stripeToken'), 'metadata' => ['Invoice', $invoice_id], ]);

        if ($charge->id) {
            $payment = new Payment();
            $payment->date = date('Y-m-d');
            $payment->method = 'stripe';
            $payment->amount = ($charge->amount / 100);
            $payment->details = $charge->id;
            $payment->save();

            if (isset($invoice_id)) {
                $invoice = Invoice::find($invoice_id);
                $payment->invoice()->associate($invoice);
                $payment->user()->associate($invoice->user);

                $payment->save();
                $invoice->updatePayment();
            } elseif ($request->has('user_id')) {
                $user = User::find($request->input('user_id'));
                $payment->user()->associate($user);
                $payment->save();
            }
        }
        return redirect()->action('InvoiceController@showPublic', ['id' => $payment->invoice->hashid()]);
    } catch (\Stripe\Exception\RateLimitException $e) {
        // Too many requests made to the API too quickly
        return back()->withErrors('Error! ' . $e->getMessage());
    } catch (\Stripe\Exception\InvalidRequestException $e) {
        // Invalid parameters were supplied to Stripe's API
        return back()->withErrors('Error! ' . $e->getMessage());
    } catch (\Stripe\Exception\AuthenticationException $e) {
        // Authentication with Stripe's API failed
        // (maybe you changed API keys recently)
        return back()->withErrors('Error! ' . $e->getMessage());
    } catch (\Stripe\Exception\ApiConnectionException $e) {
        // Network communication with Stripe failed
        return back()->withErrors('Error! ' . $e->getMessage());
    } catch (\Stripe\Exception\ApiErrorException $e) {
        // Display a very generic error to the user, and maybe send
        // yourself an email
        return back()->withErrors('Error! ' . $e->getMessage());
    } catch (Exception $e) {
        // Something else happened, completely unrelated to Stripe
        return back()->withErrors('Error! ' . $e->getMessage());
    }

```

  • PHP version: 7.3
  • Database type and version: 10.4.11-MariaDB-1:10.4.11+maria~bionic

subject: crater
title: Manual Upadate?
description: What are the steps for manually updating the application?
What's the reason for manually updating the application if there's a way to do it automatically?

See basically I had issues twice. I run two instances of crater ec2 on aws.

  • 1st Managed by Runcloud.io : So as this instance is managed by Runcloud (not good), they have a limitation of disabling few of the PHP functions in the free account. One of them is set_time_limit() used in the update process.
  • 2nd Managed by Moss.sh : So far the best for managing servers, no limitations and complete control. The thing happened when I clicked update on the application was that it installed the code base all over again, clearing out the vendor and node_modules directory. So my app was blank until I realised that I have to run composer install and npm install again. Also after I did that and went back to my app->settings->update page, there was an update available and app didn't get updated.

Currently inspecting the problem for the 2nd instance, no idea what went wrong.

That's really weird!

We don't have a way to do this manually yet, but I think it's possible to do this by cloning the github repository directly and then do a git pull everytime there's a new update.

But then comes the issue of running event listeners for each update, which are responsible for updating the database and deleting unneeded files etc and updating the version in the settings table.

For that, we'll need to create a simple artisan command which fires an UpdateFinished event or something but I feel things will break when there have been 2 major updates.

Thus, I think your best option is to install Crater on a server that doesn't have a problem with auto-updating. or let us know if there's any way we can improve the auto-update feature to support your web-service/server.

From 3.1.0 onwards we have made a few changes to make it easier for everyone to update the application like: - We are now using laravel migrations to make database changes instead of event listeners - We've divided the update process into multiple steps to make it easier to track the issue and also allow updating vendor files automatically - We've redesigned the Update app UI - Added a new crater:update command to update the application from command-line

Here's how the UI looks like now:

I think with these changes, it should be pretty easy to manually update your application.

However, we'll also add a page on craterapp.com to download update zip files just in case for users who cannot automatically update the app.

I'll keep this issue open until that's done.

subject: crater
title: [Idea] Internal Taxes
description:
Basically, an Invoice includes a fixed amount the client must pay. Let's say $100.000.

The normal tax is 15%, to say a random percentage. The amount received is $100.000, but from it $85.000 are gross income.

I've seen many payment gateways that take their cut over the amount paid, like for example 2%. That means:

  • $15.000 in state tax.
  • $2.000 in Gateway tax (costs).
  • $83.000 gross income.

It would be good to have an internal tax, not set in the invoice, but internally (after tax? post tax? internal tax?) to avoid surprises when retrieving the income from the gateway service.

yeah, thought the same, maybe even calculate things like VAT? It's quite easy. Currently I am using quickbooks online for invoicing and I really hate it :) Was thinking about writing my own and now I saw this, yay! :D

I like the idea but we need to think about how we can add it to the current flow and how this relates to current reports.

Also, many users are requesting other features like Recurring Invoices, Payment reminders & Integration with stripe (which are quite time consuming).

I am thinking that we need a way to vote on features, so we can give a higher priority to the most requested features.
One way is sort by :+1: and filter by feature request tag on the issue list
